description: Utility-scale quantum computing refers to computations that provide practical value beyond what classical computers can efficiently achieve. This represents the transition from proof-of-concept demonstrations to genuinely useful quantum computations.

The term gained prominence with IBM's 2023 demonstration on their 127-qubit Eagle processor, which computed expectation values for circuits containing thousands of two-qubit gates—beyond brute-force classical simulation capabilities.
Utility-scale experiments push the limits of qubit count, circuit depth, and measurement accuracy simultaneously, making comprehensive error mitigation strategies essential.
why_qem: At utility scale, raw hardware error rates make unmitigated results essentially random. Error mitigation is not optional—it is required to extract any signal from the computation.

The combination of multiple error mitigation techniques becomes crucial: Pauli twirling to tailor noise, PEA for accurate noise amplification, ZNE for extrapolation to zero noise, and TREX for readout correction.
Learned noise models (sparse Pauli-Lindblad) enable both PEA and PEC-style approaches without full process tomography, making mitigation practical for 100+ qubit systems.
These experiments demonstrate that error mitigation can extend quantum computing capabilities by orders of magnitude in effective circuit volume.

demonstrations.title: IBM 127-Qubit Utility Demonstration (2023)
demonstrations.description: Executed 127-qubit circuits with 60 layers of two-qubit gates, totaling 2800+ CNOT operations. Error-mitigated expectation values were accurate where classical verification was possible, and extended into classically intractable regimes.
demonstrations.techniques: Pauli twirling, PEA-based ZNE, TREX, dynamical decoupling

challenges: Verifying results in the classically intractable regime requires indirect methods
Sampling overhead for ZNE grows with circuit size
Debate continues on whether results represent true quantum utility vs. sophisticated classical simulation
Scaling to fault-tolerant quantum computing remains the ultimate goal
